newsitem.title: INDIA: India says Oman gas pipeline faces problems.
newsitem.headline: India says Oman gas pipeline faces problems.

text.p: India said on Monday that a $4 billion submarine pipeline project to supply natural gas from the Gulf state of Oman had run into problems but the two countries were trying to salvage it.

"We are confronted with the problem of technology to lay a pipeline in fairly deep waters," a foreign office spokesman told reporters, a day before Oman's Sultan Qaboos Bin Said was due to start his first official tour of India.
"There was also the question of adequate gas reserves to warrant the project. Oman is not the world's largest depositories of gas," the spokesman said.
The two countries signed a memorandum of understanding in 1993 to build the pipeline through the Arabian Sea separating them.
"The two governments decided in 1996 to set up a joint committee of experts to study whether the project was feasible. That is where it stands today," the spokesman said.
He did not say if the issue would be taken up with Qaboos who begins his four-day visit on Tuesday.
Omani officials said the Gulf state was not likely to spend more money on the feasibility study.
"We have already spent $70 to 80 million and we haven't made much headway," one Omani official told Reuters.
The proposed pipeline, more than 1,300 km (813 miles) long, was expected to hit a maximum depth of two miles.
